So I have structured this presentation into 3 segments. I will first present my research approach, followed by briefly revisiting all my research studies and then closing with the contributions that my research brings to the table.
So let's begin with the first segment.
Global organizations have long recognized and declared women's health wellbeing and empowerment as a critical development goal.
for instance, sustainable development goal. 3 places emphasis on ensuring universal access to reproductive health.

Simultaneously. Sdg, 5 promotes the use of information communication technology to achieve these goals. These global initiatives provide a context for my dissertation research, which lies at the intersection of women's health. Well being and empowerment, and the role of technology in achieving these objectives

for my dissertation for my dissertation, I have focused on the critical subdomain of menstrual health and well being. As we move forward, it is imperative to acknowledge the landscape of research. My work builds on.

notably in one of the initial efforts Kai Conference in 2,017 hosted a workshop to reimagine how technology intersects with women's health. Since then the researchers have explored technology based interventions across various women's health issues, including intimate care, maternal health, menstrual health. Among others.
when I started my research back in 2,017 the domain of menstrual health and Atci was relatively new. However, it has grown exponentially since then.

Studies have examined the role of technology at different stages of menstrual journey, focusing on menstrual literacy, material and civic infrastructures, menstrual tracking and increased data management.
it is crucial to note that while these studies have made valuable contributions, majority have primarily represented the experiences of menstruators from the mental North.
Through my dissertation, I extend these conversations within the fci community by presenting a case from India.

a context from global South, where a complex interplay between cultural practices and social and societal norms sustain acute menstrual taboos. with its vast cultural and religious diversity. India has variety of beliefs, practices, and rituals surrounding menstruation.

For instance, in many Southern and Eastern States the onset of menstruation, also known as Menaki, is celebrated as a coming of eighth ceremony. However, it is important to note that these celebrations carry an underlying notion of impurity and sacredness.
Lifestyle changes, such as seclusion, dietary control abstaining from religious activities and mandatory purification. Ritual baths are central to these celebrations.

Moreover, in certain Indian States. The sacredness of menstruation is deeply ingrained in the cultural fabric with dedicated temples, worship rituals, and festivals celebrating the menstrual cycle of deities
interestingly the sacred and impure aspect of menstruation coexist rather than contradicting each other.
